qas.question: Why did the Home Office change it rules regardin work permits in 1999?

answers.text: In response to concerns that clubs were increasingly passing over young English players in favour of foreign players

qas.question: What was one of their changes?

answers.text: A non-EU player applying for the permit must have played for his country in at least 75 per cent of its competitive 'A' team matches

qas.question: What was another requirement of foreign players?

answers.text: his country must have averaged at least 70th place in the official FIFA world rankings over the previous two years.

qas.question: Could a club appeal a requirement?

answers.text: If a player does not meet those criteria, the club wishing to sign him may appeal.

qas.question: In which year did the Home Office tighten rules on granting work permits to foreign football players?
For what percent must a player play of the competitive A team matches for which he was available for selection in the previous two years to get a work permit from the Home OFfice?
Over the last two years, what rank must a player's team average at least in order for them to receive a work permit from the Home Office?
What can a club do if a player they wish to sign does not meet the Home Office's work permit requirements?
Which entity loosened its rules in response to concerns about the clubs passing over English players?
Which entity tightened its rules in response to concerns about the clubs passing over British players?
In what year did the Home Office loosen rules for granting work permits?

plausible_answers.text: granting work permits to players from countries outside of the European Union.

qas.question: What did the Home Office loosen its rules for in 1999?
In what year did the Home Office tighten its rules for clubs wishing to sign players?

context: <a0_0>In response to concerns that clubs were increasingly passing over young English players in favour of foreign players<a0_0/>, in <a4_0><b10_0><b12_0>1999<b12_0/><b10_0/><a4_0/>, the <b8_0><b9_0>Home Office<b9_0/><b8_0/> tightened its rules for <b11_0>granting work permits to players from countries outside of the European Union.<b11_0/> <a1_0>A non-EU player applying for the permit must have played for his country in at least <a5_0>75<a5_0/> per cent of its competitive 'A' team matches<a1_0/> for which he was available for selection during the previous two years, and <a2_0>his country must have averaged at least <a6_0>70th place<a6_0/> in the official FIFA world rankings over the previous two years.<a2_0/> <a3_0>If a player does not meet those criteria, the club wishing to sign him may <a7_0>appeal<a7_0/>.
